channel.title: Javascript Explanation
channel.description:
Alright, so I'm working on something in another project and I'm trying to port vBulletin's password encryption method to another language. They encrypt the password with Javascript before sending it off to the server.
Now, I'm not much of a Javascript person (Tbh, I think it's dirty, etc.), so I got confused as to what I was looking at. Here is an example: [code] var E=(((D[B>>2]>>8*(B%4))&255)<<16)|(((D[B+1>>2]>>8*((B+1)%4))&255)<<8)|((D[B+2>>2]>>8*((B+2)%4))&255);[/code]
D is a string, B is an integer.
D[b>>2] - The brackets bother me. Is it acting like an array of characters? That doesn't make sense to me.

item.title: Javascript Explanation
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:255150”]SimpleMachines has javascript to sha1 the password before it is sent off to the server, why not just use that instead of some proprietary design that probably doesn’t even work as well?[/quote]Because I need it for vBulletin, you noob lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Explanation
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:5, topic:255150”][quote author=Mike_ link=topic=337150.msg2619257#msg2619257 date=1231269078]
wait up… why would they encrypt it with javascript?

[/quote]Instead of using say… SSL?

They encrypt it with Javascript before they send it from your computer to the server.[/quote]
oh that makes sense.

Read full topic

[quote=“OnlyOneRule, post:1, topic:255253”]Sure D isn’t an array?[/quote]I said it was a string “or an array of characters.”

l0l

item.title: Javascript Explanation
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It could just as easily be a string, d[0] would then be syntactic sugar for d.charAt(0)

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Explanation
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

D is a string, or an array of characters. b>>2 would be the index then, yes (Didn’t make sense to me either.).
(Original problem solved).

And I’m not looking in the wrong place. I took the Javascript right off of the website, heh.

That is also a year or so old.

Tele, that may be the encryption when it’s stored into the database, but this is different. Plus, I’ll never know the salt, or I shouldn’t anyways.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Explanation
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Not much of an expert myself at all, as well, but I think D is actually an array. I also believe the [tt]b>>2[/tt] is the index in the array, but that wouldn’t make as much as sense as I’d like it to make. Mind being more specific on the D and B variables?

After I typed the above paragraph, I looked into the vBulletin password encryption scenario a little more and came up with this:
http://mightyhitter.com/vbulletin-password-encryption.html

Either I am understanding you or you have been looking in the wrong place. If the former is correct, please state so and explain.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Explanation

item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Alright, so I’m working on something in another project and I’m trying to port vBulletin’s password encryption method to another language. They encrypt the password with Javascript before sending it off to the server.

Now, I’m not much of a Javascript person (Tbh, I think it’s dirty, etc.), so I got confused as to what I was looking at.
Here is an example:

var E=(((D[B>>2]>>8*(B%4))&255)<<16)|(((D[B+1>>2]>>8*((B+1)%4))&255)<<8)|((D[B+2>>2]>>8*((B+2)%4))&255);

D is a string, B is an integer.

D[b>>2] - The brackets bother me. Is it acting like an array of characters? That doesn’t make sense to me.
